content: If GaloisField p n's p and n are small, when defining a function in form of GaloisField p n -> Nat, is there something for pattern matching or split by cases for the GaloisField p n?
I think you're basically asking how to enumerate this field and if n>1 then I think you're going to have to make a choice of presentation and do it yourself
ie prove there's some x such that k=F_p[x]/(f) where f has degree n and then just use Z/pZ^n via low degree polynomials
Mathematically the moment n>1 you have different but mathematically indistinguishable elements in those fields so you're going to have to break the symmetry and AFAIK nobody did this yet
For example F_4 is 0, 1 and then two mathematically indistinguishable roots of x^2=x+1
And for bigger p even the polynomial is not canonical
I guess the other alternative would be to use that F_{p^n} has a primitive root g, choose a fixed one using AC and then it's a cyclic group with 0 and g is your generator of order p^n-1
Your choice of presentation will then be a choice of whether you want addition or multiplication to be easy
But they can't both be easy as finite fields are combinatorially subtle
It would be nice to have the formalization of finite fields using Lenstra polynomials.
